id_table_1.caption: The performance of various 3D descriptors in oversegmentation tasks on S3DIS, ScanNet dai2017scannet , and v-KITTI gaidon2016virtual  for the original (Left) and rotated (Right) scenes, respectively. Left of ’/’: Original. Right of ’/’: Rotated. We adopt random rotation of 0∘superscript00^{\circ} to 180∘superscript180180^{\circ}, and then evaluate the quality of over-segmentation in terms of rotational robustness. The backbone utilized for comparisons is unified as SparseConv graham20183d . We test the performance of oversegmentation in the 0.2% annotation percentage setting.

id_table_2.caption: The performance of various 3D descriptors in instance segmentation tasks on S3DIS, ScanNet for the original and rotated scenes, respectively. Left of ’/’: Original. Right of ’/’: Rotated. The tested annotation percentages are 0.2%, 0.4%, 0.6%, 0.8%, and 1.0% for the task of instance segmentation. The labeled points are randomly selected. We adopt random rotation of 0∘superscript00^{\circ} to 180∘superscript180180^{\circ}, and then evaluate the quality of instance segmentation in terms of rotational robustness. The backbone utilized for comparisons is unified as the SparseConv graham20183d .

id_table_3.caption: The comparisons of the performance of our proposed method on various of indoor benchmarks. For weakly supervised semantic/instance segmentation, various test settings of 0.03%, 0.2%, and 1.0% labeled points are experimented on ScanNet for comparisons. The setting of ”One Pt.” represents merely one labeled point for each class within the whole scene instead of small blocks (e.g. 1×1×11111\times 1\times 1 cubic meters) of Xu et al. xu2020weakly . The backbone utilized for comparisons is unified as SparseConv graham20183d . All experimental results are three times on average.

id_table_4.caption: The comparisons of the performance of our proposed method on outdoor benchmarks Semantic3D hackel2017semantic3d  and SemanticKITTI behley2019semantickitti  for the semantic segmentation task. The setting of One Pt. represents merely one labeled point for each instance class within the whole scene instead of small blocks (e.g. 1×1×11111\times 1\times 1 cubic meters) of Xu et al.. The diverse percentages of label ratios are tested. The backbone utilized for comparisons is unified as SparseConv. All experimental results are three times on average.

id_table_5.caption: The comparisons of the performance of our proposed method on outdoor benchmarks KITTI and Waymo for the 3D object detection task in the 1% and 3% annotated bounding box case. The one box case denotes merely one randomly selected bounding box is annotated within ten point cloud scenes (0.5% label). The backbone utilized for comparisons is unified as SparseConv. All experimental results are three times on average. The mAPH denotes mean average precision weighted by heading. The Level-2 represents the level-2 detection difficulty, which is harder than level-1.

id_table_6.caption: Data efficient indoor 3D instance segmentation average precision (AP%) results with limited number of scene reconstructions compared with TWIST on ScanNet with SparseConv as the backbone network.

id_table_7.caption: RM3D transfer learning performance for the task of the instance segmentation (Metric: AP@50%) on the ScanNet/S3DIS validation Set. The Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} is selected as the similarity of our proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor. The annotation percentage is 0.2% for the semantic and instance segmentation tasks and approximately 1% for the object detection task. S3 →→\rightarrow Sc denotes transferring trained model on S3DIS to ScanNet, and Sc →→\rightarrow S3 denotes transferring trained model on ScanNet to S3DIS, respectively.

id_table_8.caption: RM3D ablation study of the influence of the proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} and other diverse features on indoor ScanNet (Left Value) and S3DIS (Right Value) validation set, for the task of semantic segmentation (Metric: mIoU%), and instance segmentation (Metric: AP@50%) with the 0.2% labeled points per scene case. The Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} is selected as the similarity of our proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor.

id_table_9.caption: RM3D ablation study of the influence of the proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} and other diverse features on outdoor Waymo (Left Value) and KITTI (Right Value) validation set, for the task of Waymo object detection (Metric: mAPH%), and and KITTI object detection (Metric: AP%) with the 1% label percentage. The Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} is selected as the similarity of our proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor.

id_table_10.caption: RM3D ablation study of the network modules on ScanNet (Left Value) and S3DIS (Right Value) validation set, for the tasks of semantic segmentation (Metric: mIoU%), and instance segmentation (Metric: AP@50%) with 0.2% labeled points per scene case. The Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} is selected as the similarity of our proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor.

id_table_11.caption: RM3D ablation study of the network modules on Waymo with the evaluation metric of mAPH%percent\% (Left Value) and KITTI with the evaluation metric of AP%percent\% (Right Value) validation set, for the tasks of object detection with 0.2% labeled points per scene case. The ✓✓\checkmark-1 denotes using LA​u​gj​ssubscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑗𝑠𝐴𝑢𝑔L^{js}_{Aug} for the network optimizations, and ✓✓\checkmark-2 denotes using LA​u​gm​s​esubscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑚𝑠𝑒𝐴𝑢𝑔L^{mse}_{Aug} for the network optimizations. The Mdessubscript𝑀desM_{\mbox{{\tiny{{des}}}}} is selected as the similarity of our proposed adapted PFH-based 3D local descriptor.

id_table_12.caption: RM3D ablation study of the network optimization loss functions for the task of 3D object detection on ScanNet validation set (Metric: AP@50%) with two annotated bounding boxes (approximately 1%) per ten scenes.

id_table_13.caption: RM3D ablation study of the network optimization loss functions for the task of the object detection on KITTI (Metric: AP%, left value) and Waymo validation set (Metric: mAPH%, right value) with two annotated bounding boxes (approximately 1%) per ten scenes.
